dsDescriptionValue.value: The Canadian National Mobility Study was carried out by Statistics Canada and is similar to the 1962 and 1973 Occupational Changes in a Generation Surveys (Featherman and Hauser, 1975). The study questions were an addition to the Statistics Canada regular force survey and is focused on rates and patterns of intergenerational occupational mobility in the Canadian population. Data are available for about 45,000 non-institutionalized respondents age 18 and over. Questions include details on education and occupation of parents, family size and structure, urban-rural status, respondent's education, work history, and occupational status. Other topics cover migration and immigration, ethnicity, languages spoken, religion, marital status, and number of children.

publicationCitation.value: Boyd, Monica. "Occupational attainment of native born Canadian women: Results from the 1973 Canadian National Mobility Study". CDE Working Paper 77-26 (http://www.ssc.wisc.edu/cde/cdewp/77-26.pdf)
Boyd, Monica and Hugh A. McRoberts. Design of the 1973 Canadian National Mobility Study on Occupational and Educational Change in a Generation. Conference publication, 1974.

Treiman, Donald J. "A Standard Occupational Prestige Scale for Use with Historical Data"  The Journal of Interdisciplinary History. Vol. 7, No. 2, Social Mobility in past Time (Autumn, 1976), pp. 283-304
Treiman, Donald J. Occupational Prestige in Comparative Perspective. New York: Academic Press, Inc., Ltd., 1977.

distributorAffiliation.value: Carleton University. Department of Sociology and Anthropology

value: Individuals age 18 years and over living in Canada

fields.value: Multi-stage stratified cluster sample was designed to represent the non-institutional adult Canadian population. File contains data for 21,751 males (data copying resulted in loss of one male, so n of men=21750, and the number of females=23,116.
For weighting, use the final universal weight (VAR100) to represent the population, not the labor force weight (VAR020. This latter one is inappropriate for the mobility study population.

Non-response rates to the question on current occupation in the labor force are high for the categories of self-employed and unpaid family work, particularly for women where the non-response rates are 69% for female unpaid workers and 34% for female self-employed workers. (Boyd 1984. International migration review. Vol 18. No. 4 (Winter 1984) pp. 1091-1119.
